misconceptions.name: Missing conditional to filter even numbers
misconceptions.description: Score: 0/1. The program never checks whether a number is even (using n % 2 == 0 or similar), so it cannot selectively sum even inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe the task is to compute an average acceleration from given parameters, with no need to distinguish even and odd numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use a conditional (if statement) to test each input number with n % 2 == 0 and only add it to the sum when this condition is true.
symptoms: No use of the modulus operator %
No if statement related to even/odd checks
Computation is purely arithmetic on v0, v1, and t
misconceptions.root_cause: The implemented algorithm does not address the requirement to filter on evenness; it is solving a different mathematical problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Within the input-processing loop, add an if (n % 2 == 0) check before adding the number to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: A full scan of the code shows no conditional that checks n % 2 == 0 or any even/odd logic.

evidence.note: The core computation uses a formula for acceleration; there is no conditional logic related to even numbers anywhere in the program.

No accumulator variable for a sum of multiple inputs
Output message refers to average acceleration, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented the wrong problem, focusing on a physics formula rather than accumulation over multiple inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an int sum = 0; update sum += n inside the even-number check, and at the end print "Sum of even numbers: " + sum. misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no sum variable, no repeated addition, and the final print statement clearly targets a different problem.
